Ni/zeolite catalyst, as well as a series of modified molybdenum MoNi/zeolite catalysts (zeolite = ZSM-5, ZSM-23, MOR, Y) were investigated in the hydroprocessing of an undiluted fatty acid mixture in a batch reactor at a temperature of 350 °C and an initial hydrogen pressure of 60 bar. The highest conversion (70 %) of the fatty acid mixture was achieved over ZSM-5 supported catalytic system in 7 h. The fresh and spent catalytic systems were characterized by XRD, TEM, TPR-H2, TPD-NH3, CHNS. Influence of the support, and the modifier, on the catalytic activity, stability under reaction conditions, and selectivity to iso-alkanes were shown. Leaching of the active component from the surface of all catalysts was found. The largest amount of residual nickel was observed in catalysts based on ZSM-5 zeolite - ca.57 % of the initial metal content. Modification with molybdenum did not improve the stability of catalysts to metal leaching. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Undiluted fatty acid One-pot process Hydrodeoxygenation Zeolite Nickel 1 Introduction Fossil derived fuels still account for a significant share of energy production, negatively affecting the global efforts to combat climate change [1]. The use of the biofuels as a fossil-derived substitute, an approach being promoted by the EU, is regarded as an effective strategy during a transition period towards greener economy [2]. Biofuels are considered especially relevant for aviation and heavy-duty transport, which still rely on the use of liquid motor fuels [3]. Vegetable oils [4], microalgae lipids [5], waste cooking oils [6], soapstock [7] are considered raw materials for the production of renewable fuels. Hydroprocessing of various vegetable lipids and waste vegetable oils makes it possible to obtain fuels similar in their characteristics to the fossil derived counterparts [8]. Traditional approach towards the production of motor fuels from vegetable feed-stock includes two consecutive stages. Firstly, the material is deoxygenated (oxygen is present as a part of plant lipids), yielding normal alkanes. Secondly, the material is subjected to isomerization treatment to improve the octane number of the produced fuel, since fossil-derived motor fuels contain not only normal alkanes, but also aromatics and iso-alkanes. The presence of iso-alkanes and aromatic compounds also improves fuel cold flow properties [9]. Deoxygenation process was reported to be catalyzed by several noble (Pt, Pd, Rh) and transition (Ni, Co, Mo, W in sulfided and unsulfided forms) metals [4,10]. The production of iso-alkanes, on the other hand, is achieved via the second stage, i.e. hydroisomerization. This process is typically carried out on catalysts with active components similar to the ones listed above (platinum group metals: Pt, Pd; transition: Ni) supported on acidic carriers [11]. In terms of the latter, one should mention amorphous oxides or mixtures of oxides, silicoaluminophosphates, mesoporous materials, and zeolites [9], which have recently been widely studied both in hydroisomerization [12], as well as in combined hydrodeoxygenation and hydroisomerization processes [9,10]. It is important to highlight that similarity of the catalytic systems for the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization stages makes it possible to combine these two reactions in a one-pot process [9], which is also beneficial from an economic and operational point of view. Despite a wide range of works [4,9,10] on the use of catalysts with an active component based on noble metals, as well as catalysts based on transition metals Ni, Co, Mo, W in sulfided and non-sulfided forms in processes hydroprocessing of plant lipids, these catalysts have their drawbacks. Firstly, catalysts based on noble metals are costly, which may limit their use, in particular at an industrial scale [10]. On the other hand, sulfided catalysts based on transition metals require additional introduction of sulfur into the reaction medium in order to maintain an active state [10]. In addition, a common problem of this catalytic systems is their deactivation during the plant lipids hydroprocessing. With respect to the most relevant reasons of catalyst deactivation, during plant lipids hydroprocessing [13] one should mention the issue of coke formation [14–18]. Literature seems to suggest that in a limited number of cases, catalyst annealing makes it possible to restore catalytic activity [19,20], whereas other sources indicate the opposite [21,22]. This discrepancy can be associated with both incomplete removal of coke and other reasons for the deactivation. Indeed, under hydrodeoxygenation/hydroisomerization conditions, catalysts may experience deactivation due to sintering of the active component [14,23,24]; poisoning [25–27]; leaching of the active component [23,28–30]. The latter mechanism, i.e. active component loss due to substrate organic acid attack, proves to be particularly problematic. The mitigation strategies are primarily based on two approaches: modification of the reaction medium and catalyst doping. For the former, several reported studies demonstrate that diluting substrate material with the solvent helps to alleviate the problem [31–33]. At the same time, another set of works suggests that dilution does not always prevent the leaching of the active component [28–30,34]. It should be noted that there are practically no works where the effect of leaching of the active component in the hydroprocessing of neat plant lipids feed-stock is studied. The doping strategy is pursued with the used of, in particular, modification with transition metals (Mo [35], W [36], Co [37], Cu [38]). This allows not only to increase the stability [38], but also to improve the catalytic activity in the deoxygenation processes [35–37]. In light of the above, present work strives to address these gaps in understanding of the topic of deoxygenation/hydroisomerization of fatty acids. To this end, a set of Ni-catalysts supported on different zeolite supports (Y, MOR, ZSM-23, and ZSM-5) were used to evaluate the impact of the composition on their stability and catalytic performance in the process of hydroprocessing of an undiluted mixture of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids. In addition, using Mo as a doping agent, the influence of this component on the catalytic performance and stability towards leaching under reaction conditions was examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Supports (Zeolyst International, USA): mordenite, MOR (CBV-21A) with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 20 and zeolite ZSM-5 (CBV-3024E) with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 30 were received in NH4 +–forms; zeolites Y (CBV 720) with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 30 and ZSM-23 (ZD15001) with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 48 were received in H+-forms. Nickel (II) nitrate Ni(NO3)2*6H2O (Reahim, Russia), ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate (NH4)6Mo7O24*4H2O (Reahim, Russia). Oleic acid (technical grade, Reahim, Russia) (hereinafter referred to as FAs mixture), the composition of which is presented in Table 1, was used as a model raw material. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The H+-forms of mordenite and ZSM-5 zeolites were obtained by thermal decomposition of NH4 +-forms by calcination in air at a temperature of 550 °C for 3 h and 5 h for ZSM-5 and MOR structures, respectively. Nickel-based catalysts were prepared by supporting the active component on MOR, ZSM-5, ZSM-23, Y at 5 wt.% using incipient wetness impregnation technique. A water solution of nickel nitrate was used as a precursor. After impregnation, the samples were dried in air at 120 °C for 1 h and calcined at 550 °C for 2 h. Catalysts were reduced in an H2-flow at an atmospheric pressure and 550 °C for 1 h, followed by the ethanol quenching. Preparation of bimetallic catalysts was carried out by a successive impregnation of 5%Ni/zeolite samples with a solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24*4H2O to obtain a 5%Ni-1%Mo/zeolite catalyst. The obtained samples were dried in air at 120 °C for 1 h and calcined at 550 °C for 2 h. This was followed by an H2-reduction at an atmospheric pressure and 550 °C for 1 h, followed by the ethanol quenching. The list of supports and catalysts used is presented in Table 2. 2.3 Physicochemical methods for studying catalysts The elemental composition of the fresh, spent catalysts and liquid products was determined using an ARL Advantage'X 2247 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with Rh anode as an X-ray source. Mass percentage of elements was estimated using QuantAS software. Also, elemental analysis of the fresh and spent catalysts was carried out using the method of atomic emission spectroscopy with inductively coupled plasma (ICP-AES) on Optima 4300 DV (Perkin Elmer Inc. USA). Textural characteristics of supports and catalysts were measured by N2 physical adsroption at liquid nitrogen temperature using at automated volumetric adsorption unit Autosorb Station 4 (USA). Samples were kept at 50 °C for 4 h before analysis. Specific surface area and total pore volume (according to the limiting saturation at relative pressure p/p0 = 1) were calculated using BET method, and the pore size distribution was calculated using the BJH method on the desorption branch of adsorption [39] and the NLDFT method. The specific surface area and the volume of micropores were calculated by the t-method [40]. The study of the acidity of supports and Ni-containing catalysts by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3) was carried out in a U-shaped quartz reactor, the weight of the sample was 100 mg (0,25–0,50 mm particle size), the heating rate was 8 °C/min. Cumulative amount of acid sites (AS) was calculated via integrating the area of the TPD-NH3 profile in respective ranges: before 250 °C, 250–450 °C, and above 450 °C for weak, medium and strong AS, respectively [39,41]. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the catalysts was carried out in 10 vol% H2, balance Ar gas mixture at 20 ml/min; typical sample weight was 200 mg (0,25–0,50 mm particle size). The samples were placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor and heated in a reducing atmosphere at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min until a temperature of 900 °C was reached. The change in the hydrogen concentration in the mixture at the outlet of the reactor was recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Germany) with monochromated CuKa radiation (λ = 1,5418 Å) and LynxEye (1D) linear detector, in 4–70° 2θ range at 0,05° step, and an accumulation time of 3 s for each data point. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was carried out using a transmission electron microscope JEM-2010 from JEOL (Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV and a resolution of 0,14 nm. CHNS was done using CHNS-O element analyzer VARIO EL CUBE from Elementar Analysensysteme (Germany). Gas chromatography was done on Agilent 7820B (USA), equipped with FID detector and ZB-5 column, using the following program: 50 °C for 2 min, T-ramp to 280 °C at 8 °C/min, followed by a 2 min soak at the same temperature. Ar at 2 ml/min was used as a carrier gas. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement Hydroprocessing activity measurements in the mixture of fatty acids was carried out in 500 ml autoclave batch reactor. Typical catalyst loading per experiment was 3,5 g mixed with the ca 0,150 ml of the FA mixture. Catalytic activity was evaluated for 7 h at 6,0 MPa H2 initial pressure with 1000 rpm stirring. Reaction time was counted from the moment the system would achieve the target temperature (350 °C). The pressure in the system during the experiment was greater than the initial pressure. It was 10±2 MPa and practically did not change during the experiment. Collected product samples were treated with hexamethyldisilane (HDMS) in 1:1 vol. ratio for 1 h at ca 70 °C prior to the GC analysis. Feedstock conversion (X) was calculated as follows (1): (1) X = 1 − n n 0 * 100 % where n is the amount of unreacted FA mixture, n 0 is the initial amount of the FA mixture. Process selectivity (Si) was calculated according to Eq. (2). (2) S i = n i ∑ n i * 100 % where ni is the amount of the i th product in the liquid phase and Σni is the total amount of products in the liquid phase. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characteristics of supports and catalysts The study of samples by low-temperature nitrogen adsorption showed that mono- and bimetallic catalysts contain all types of pores (see Supplementary Informantion Fig. 1S) with a predominance of micropores ( Table 3, Fig. 2S). For catalysts based on Y, MOR, and ZSM-23 zeolites, the deposition of nickel led to a decrease in the specific surface area (SSA), which can indicate both metal deposition on the external surface and inside the pores of the zeolite [28,39,41]. Specifically, for the case of Ni deposition onto Y and MOR zeolites, was observed the blocking of both micro- and meso-macropores. For the monometallic catalysts based on ZSM-23 and ZSM-5, a significant decrease in the specific surface area of micropores was observed, while that of meso-macropores was increased instead (Table 3, Fig. 2S). This phenomenon is tentatively ascribed to the partial destruction of the support micropores [39,42]. Contrary to other systems in a set, for the case of a catalyst based on ZSM-5, Ni deposition did not result in a change of SSA. This behavior could be ascribed by the net neutral impact of two opposite-direction effects, i.e. a simultaneous decrease in SSA of micropores due to a blockage by metal particles [28], and an increase in the specific surface area of meso/macropores due to their formation from merging micropores [39,42]. The modification of nickel-containing catalysts with Mo practically did not change SSA of the catalysts based on Y, ZSM-5, and MOR zeolites (Table 3), which may be due to the low content of Mo. This observation is also corroborated by a nearly complete overlap of the pore size distribution for mono- and bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 1S, Fig. 2S). In the case of Ni/ZSM-23 catalyst, SSA of this system significantly decreased during modification, primarily due to a decrease in the surface area of micropores, which indicates their blocking by metal particles [28,41]. 3.2 Acid-base properties of carriers and catalysts Fig. 1 features TPD-NH3 profiles of supports and respective catalytic systems. For all samples, a large maximum is observed in the region up to 400 °C, which relate to weak adsorption of ammonia on the acid sites (AS) of Si-OH structure [21,43], and a less pronounced peak in the region of 400–575 °C, ascribed to a strong adsorption of ammonia on Al-OH, Al-OH-Si acid groups located on the surface and inside zeolite structure [21,43]. Based on the presented data, the supports can be arranged according to their acidity in the following order: Y < ZSM-23 < ZSM-5 < MOR. Table 4 features a summary on the amount of individual type AS measured by TPD-NH3, including weak (below 250 °C), medium (250–450 °C) and strong (above 450 °C) sites. Considering the zeolite supported catalysts, one should mention the following. All TPD-NH3 profiles of monometallic systems (Fig. 1) demonstrate a large peak at 170–220 °C, attributed to weak acid sites (AS), and a small maximum in the region of 485–535 °C, representing strong AS. In the temperature range of 370–450 °C, for catalysts based on MOR, ZSM-5, and ZSM-23 zeolites, a small peak is observed, which may correspond to medium-strength AS. Arguably the same type of AS is represented by a shoulder in the case of NiY. In summary, monometallic catalysts can be arranged in the following order in terms of total acidity: NiZSM-23 < NiY < NiZSM-5 < NiMOR. The deposition of nickel on zeolites MOR, ZSM-23, and ZSM-5 led to a decrease of strong AS (Table 4), which indicates the predominant interaction of the deposited metal with this type of acid sites [44,45], as well as the blocking of pores of the supports [46]. Due to this, the force of interaction of the metal with the support increases and, consequently, the subsequent reduction of the metal phase becomes more difficult [44,47]. For the catalyst on zeolite Y, an increase in the number of strong acid sites was observed, which may be due to the desorption of ammonia from metal particles localized in the micropores of the support [48], as well as to a greater dispersion of metal particles [49]. For NiY and NiMOR catalysts, an introduction of Ni increased the amount of weak and medium-strength AS. Previously, it was argued that an increase in the number of such sites can be associated with the presence of oxide forms of Ni [50,51]. For the catalysts based on ZSM-23 and ZSM-5, surface concentration of weak-/medium-strength AS was not affected by the deposition of the active component, which may indicate the existence of predominantly metallic form of Ni in these catalysts. Analysis of the TPD-NH3 profiles for bimetallic systems (Fig. 1) reveals the presence of a large peak in the temperature range up to 200 °C, which refers to the weak AS, and a smaller peak at temperature above 400 °C, attributed to strong AS. For catalysts based on MOR, ZSM-23, and ZSM-5 zeolites, a small shoulder is observed in the temperature range from 200 °C to 400 °C, which correspond to medium-strength AS. For all catalysts, except for the sample on zeolite Y, the modification of Ni catalyst with Mo led to an increase in the total acidity of the sample (Table 4) due to an increase in the number of medium-strength AS. This may be associated with the formation of new acid sites such as Mo-OH, Mo6+ [44]. In case of NiY catalyst, the acidity decreased due to a decrease in the number of strong AS, which, in turn, decrease due to the blocking of micropores [46]. As a result of this analysis, bimetallic samples can be arranged in the following order in terms of total acidity: MoNiY < MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiMOR. 3.3 Temperature-programmed reduction Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of Ni-catalysts are characterized by three regions where different components experience reduction in hydrogen: i. below 350 °C, for weakly bound or bulk NiO [35,52], ii. 350–500 °C, for NiO strongly bound to the support [35,52,53], and iii. above 500 °C, for NiO-Al2O3 pseudospinels [53], NiAl2O4 spinels [35,52], highly dispersed NiO particles [53–55] or NiO particles located inside the pores of the support [48]. Analysis of the TPR profiles ( Fig. 2) recorded for NiMOR reveals the presence of a single peak in 350–500 °C region and practically no absorption of H2 above 500 °C. For NiZSM-23, one peak is observed in 350–500 °C range and a shoulder above 500 °C. For catalysts based on Y and ZSM-5, curve maximums are observed in 350–500 °C range and above 500 °C, with the second peak of the NiZSM-5 curve featuring higher intensity. For NiY the reduction of nickel oxide up to 1000 °C was also observed, which can be ascribed to NiO inside the support micropores [48]. The percentage of bulk NiO on the surface of all samples is very low, as evidenced by a small shoulder in 250–300 °C region. Using Ni fraction reducible in the region above 500 °C, catalysts can be positioned in the following order: NiMOR (30 %) < NiZSM-23 (35 %) < NiY (53 %) ~ NiZSM-5 (54 %). TPR profile of MoNiMOR exhibited one peak in 350–500 °C region, with little to no absorption of hydrogen above 500 °C. MoNiY data features a single curve maximum in 350–500 °C region and a shoulder above 500 °C. One peak above 500 °C is observed for both cases of the catalysts supported on ZSM-23 and ZSM-5 with a shoulder in 350–500 °C region. Modification of the Ni catalysts with Mo led to high temperature shifts of the peak positions for the majority of the systems. Interestingly, for the catalyst based on ZSM-5, a low-T shift was observed. This observation together with an increase in the intensity of the reduction maxima are attributed to the interaction of the oxide forms of Mo6+ with weakly bound forms of NiO to form NiMoO4 structures [35,56]. The latter are reduced at the higher temperature than the initial weakly bound to the support NiO particles present in NiZSM-5. Mo-modification also led to a decrease in the fraction of bulk NiO (a decrease of the TPR-intensity of the shoulder in the T-region below 350 °C), indicating the formation of Ni-Mo phases. Using an approach, similar to the above, one can arrange bimetallic catalysts based on the active component fraction reducible above 500 °C: MoNiMOR (29 %) < MoNiY (51 %) < MoNiZSM-23 (58 %) < MoNiZSM-5 (65 %). 3.4 Activity of Ni and Mo-Ni catalysts in fatty acids hydroprocessing Fig. 3 features the product distribution data for the hydroprocessing of a mixture of fatty acids (FAs) in a batch reactor at 350 °C on mono- and bimetallic catalysts. As can be seen, the main products in the liquid phase were: isoalkanes, alkanes (n-alkanes), FAs with shorter chain length than the initial substrate molecules (C6–C15), and aromatic hydrocarbons. С15–С19 linear alkanes likely formed during deoxygenation of the initial FAs along the route of hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), decarboxylation and/or decarbonylation (DC) [57]. Formation of C6–C15 FAs were a result of the hydrocracking of the original C16–C20 FAs. N-alkanes with a chain length C5–C14 formed in the process of hydrocracking of C15–C19 alkanes (from previous process steps) and during the deoxygenation of FAs with a chain length C6–C15. N-alkanes available in the product mixture were also the feed-stock for the formation of C5–C19 isoalkanes and C6–C10 aromatics in a dehydrocyclization process. Table 5 presents the values of conversion and selectivity measured after 7 h of FAs hydroprocessing. The lowest conversion values were measured for MOR supported systems (25–40 %), while catalysts supported on ZSM-5 featured the best performance in the set (ca. 70 %). Mono- and bimetallic catalysts can be ranked in their performance as follows: NiMOR < NiZSM-23 < NiY < NiZSM-5; MoNiMOR < MoNiY < MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiZSM-5. In the processes of deoxygenation of plant lipids, the activity of catalysts is often associated with the particle size of the active component. Particle size greatly affects the catalysts’ reducibility - dispersed particles are reduced at higher temperatures. In turn, the particle size can be affected by the acidity [58,59] and porosity [55,60] of the supports. Our resulting catalyst conversion sequences correlate with the fraction of the active component reducible above 500 °C (refer to TPR data discussed above). At variance, for a particular case of NiY (X = 48 %) vs. NiZSM-5 (X = 71 %) comparison, both catalysts feature similar amount of Ni reducible above 500 °C in TPR experiments. These outlier FA conversion results may be related to the location NiO inside zeolite-Y micropores, that allow for a reaction with highly mobile H2 in TPR experiment, but render active component only partially available to larger substrate molecules subjected to hydroprocessing. According to the literature data [35,61,62], the modification of nickel catalysts with molybdenum can increase the activity of the catalyst in the deoxygenation of plant lipids. However, doping of MOR-supported catalysts with Mo led to a decrease in the FAs final conversion, apparently due to an increase in hydrogen uptake in 350–500 °C region and a decrease in the fraction of the form of the active component reducible above 500 °C. In the case of catalysts supported on Y and ZSM-5, modification with Mo practically did not affect the final conversion, whereas MoNiZSM-23 showed superior performance compared to NiZSM-23 (Table 5). The latter observation is in line with a change in the fraction of the high-temperature form of the active component (see TPR data). Thus, the fraction of the high-temperature form of the active component determined the activity of the catalyst during the hydroprocessing of the FAs mixture. Process selectivity with respect to several key reaction product species after 7 h are featured in Table 5. Carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, as well as methane, ethane, propane and butane were found in the gas phase. Selectivity for these products is shown in Table 1S. The target products in this process are isoalkanes. Considering the monometallic systems, the lowest selectivity to isoalkanes (S iso) was achieved on NiMOR and NiZSM-23 catalysts at ca. 45–46 %, with the rest of the catalysts in the set showing S iso in 52–54 % range. Monometallic catalysts are ranked as follows (S iso): NiMOR < NiZSM-23 < NiY < NiZSM-5. Similarly, for the case of bimetallic catalysts, the highest S iso was achieved for the MoNiZSM-23 catalyst (56 %), the lowest – for MoNiMOR (36 %). With respect to S iso all bimetallic catalysts in the set can be arranges as follows: MoNiMOR < MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiY < MoNiZSM-23. Generally, the results obtained agree with the literature data, where high selectivity to isoalkanes was repeatedly shown on catalysts based on ZSM-5 (MFI) and ZSM-23 (MTT) zeolites [41,63,64]. Their high selectivity to iso-alkanes is associated with acidic properties, as well as with the optimal size of their pores and channels [12,41,65]. As can be seen, however, ranking the monometallic catalysts with respect to the relative content of AS of these types (NiZSM-23 < NiY < NiZSM-5 < NiMOR) does not seem to correlate with individual systems’ S iso. The same is observed in bimetallic systems: MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiY < MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiMOR. As can be seen Mo-doping did not affect S iso. Overall, one can observe little to no correlation between the surface acidity and S iso data. It could indicate that (similar to the case of monometallic systems above), S iso is controlled not only by the quantity but also by accessibility of the AS [66]. A mismatch between a pore size and a kinetic diameter of a reactant can confine the reaction to the outer surface of a zeolite particle [67]. Shape selectivity of zeolites is described using Constraint Index (CI) [69] for 10-membered ring zeolites (ZSM-23, ZSM-5) and Spaciousness Index (SI) for 12-membered ring zeolites (MOR, Y) [68]. The lower the CI of a given zeolite, the larger the channels and consequently lower the steric hindrance for the reaction. SI is a similar concept, with values working in the opposite direction, viz. an increase in the SI indicates a decrease in steric hindrance inside zeolite channels. Therefore, the resulting isoalkane selectivity series shown above can be interpreted as a decrease of CI when moving from ZSM-23 to ZSM-5 ( Table 6). With a further decrease in CI, in the case of Y and MOR zeolites, a decrease in selectivity to isoalkanes was observed (Table 5). This may be due to the fact that the linear alkanes formed during the deoxygenation of fatty acids diffuse too quickly out of the large channels avoiding hydroisomerization [12,41]. For the Y zeolite, the increased selectivity to iso-alkanes may be due to a change in the zeolite structure, which imposes additional diffusion restrictions, thereby changing the CI value. This allows the resulting linear alkanes to be converted to iso-alkanes. It is worth mentioning, that 8-membered ring openings in MOR have dimensions equal or lower (2,6 × 5,7 Å, see Table 6) to the average diameter of molecules of mono- and double-branched isoalkanes: 5,0–6,2 Å and 7,0 Å, respectively [12]. With respect to the aromatics, NiZSM-5 demonstrated the highest selectivity (S Ar = 25 %) for this reaction product in the set of monometallic catalysts. This may be attributed to the relatively high content in this catalyst of Brönsted and strong acid centers, responsible for the aromatization processes [73]. The highest S Ar for the bimetallic catalysts was achieved on MoNiZSM-5 (ca. 27 %), whereas other evaluated systems showed selectivity of 6–12 % only. Mo-doping negatively affected S Ar in catalysts based on Y, MOR, and ZSM-23, which may be due to the blocking of strong AS of the support. This hypothesis is further corroborated by the fact that for the case of MoNiZSM-5, where Mo introduction increased the content of strong AS, S Ar was higher than for NiZSM-5. The highest overall S Ar for NiZSM-5 and MoNiZSM-5, can also be ascribed to the optimal CI value, allowing aromatic molecules formed inside zeolite channel to diffuse out quickly avoiding further reactions (hydrocracking, etc.) [67]. A more detailed analysis of the aromatic fraction is presented in the Table 2S. Hydrocracking occurring during FAs hydroprocessing manifested itself via the formation of FAs with chain lengths (C6-C15) shorter than the initial substrate molecules. The highest selectivity (18 %) with respect to shorter FAs was achieved on NiMOR catalyst, the lowest (4 %) – on NiZSM-5. Monometallic catalysts can be ranked in terms of shorter FAs selectivity as follows: NiZSM-5 < NiY < NiZSM-23 < NiMOR. Among the bimetallic catalysts, the highest selectivity to shorter FAs (20 %) was also shown by a catalyst supported on MOR, the lowest (3 %) – MoNiZSM-5. Bimetallic catalysts can be ranked in terms of shorter FAs selectivity is: MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiY < MoNiMOR. The modification of Ni-catalysts with Mo increased the selectivity to C6–C15 FAs in the case of Y and MOR supported systems, while a decrease in selectivity was observed for MoNiZSM-5 and MoNiZSM-23. Strong AS of zeolites are believed to promote hydrocracking processes [41,65]. In this respect the catalysts can be ranked as follows (relative content of strong AS): NiZSM-5 < NiY < NiZSM-23 < NiMOR , and MoNiY < MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiMOR. Whereas a good match between the shorter FAs selectivity and the number of strong AS is observed for the monometallic systems, for their Mo-containing counterparts the correlation is less evident. The latter observation could be attributed to an interplay between product selectivity and catalytic activity, i.e. the higher the deoxygenating ability of the catalysts (Table 5), the smaller the amount of FAs with different chain lengths present in the reaction mixture. Summarizing the results of the catalytic evaluation, it was shown that ZSM-5 supported systems to feature the best performance among both mono- and bimetallic catalysts, showing the highest ratio of iso-alkanes to linear alkanes (Table 5). The major drawback of ZSM-5 as a support material was high selectivity to aromatics, the content of which should be limited in the final fuel (25–35 %) [9]. The increased content of the active component reducible above 500 °С (TPR data) correlates with the growth in FAs conversion activity both on Ni- and Mo-Ni catalysts. The fraction of such high-temperature form of the active component is controlled by the combination of textural and acidic properties of the support. The highest selectivity to isoalkanes was achieved on NiZSM-5 and MoNiZSM-23, for mono- and bimetallic catalysts, respectively. The obtained experimental data indicate that Siso is dependent on the diffusion limitations inside the pores of the zeolites. 3.5 Characterization of spent catalysts Fig. 4 features TEM images measured for the monometallic catalysts. Active component particle size ranks the fresh catalysts as follows: NiZSM-5 < NiY < NiZSM-23 < NiMOR ( Table 7). It should be noted that FAs conversion increases with a decrease in the nickel particle size, consistent with the previously reported studies on hydrodeoxygenation of vegetable lipids [23,74]. Yet another correlation is the fact that smaller Ni particles are observed in catalysts with higher fraction of the form of the active component, reducible above 500 °C (TPR). This is ascribed to lower surface mobility of oxidized metal species, less prone to sintering than the forms of the active component resulting from the early reduction (350–500 °C) [74]. For all monometallic catalysts, exposure to the reaction conditions changes Ni particle size distribution (PSD). NiMOR and NiZSM-23 experience an increase in the average particle size of Ni ( Fig. 5). This effect is associated with the processes of sintering of metal particles during the process [23,74]. For NiZSM-5, however, Ni PSD of the spent catalyst shifted to smaller average size and became narrower, all of which is attributed to leaching of the active component [28]. Similar phenomenon is observed for NiY where PSD becomes narrower in spent catalyst, although the average size of Ni-particles remains virtually unchanged (Fig. 5). When comparing the data in Fig. 5 with the TPR data (Fig. 2), it should be concluded that for catalysts in which the active component is predominantly strongly bound to the zeolite, active component particle agglomeration is not observed, but its leaching is noted, which leads to a decrease in the average particle size in catalysts NiZSM-5 and NiY. For NiMOR and NiZSM-23 catalysts, there is competition between two processes, leaching and agglomeration of active component, with the second one process dominating. The formation of cavities in the Y zeolite particle is also observed (Fig. 4), which may be associated with the dealumination process under acidic conditions [75,76]. XRD patterns of fresh monometallic and bimetallic catalysts feature peaks characteristic of Ni in a metallic form and the support ( Fig. 6). For the bimetallic systems, XRD peaks of Mo-, Ni-oxides phases or combined Mo-Ni phases were not detected. Similarly, XRD patterns of spent catalysts show exclusively the presence of metallic Ni and the support. For ZSM-5 and MOR supported spent catalysts one can only identify the XRD presence of the support. In comparison with the fresh state, XRD pattern of a spent Y-supported catalysts show a significant intensity attenuation together with the appearance of a halo at 2θ 18–28°, which may be due to the destruction of the zeolite structure due to the process of dealumination under acidic conditions (confirmed by TEM, Fig. 4) [75,76]. Crystallite sizes (as coherent scattering domains, CSD) of Ni in fresh and spent catalysts, estimated via Scherrer’s equation from the highest intensity Ni(111) peak are listed in Table 7. As can be seen, FAs hydroprocessing leads to a CSD size decrease for the majority of the samples, which is presumably associated with redispersion or leaching of the active component [77]. MoNiZSM-23 is an exception to this trend, with a spent catalyst featuring larger CSD than the fresh counterpart. Apparently, the effect of leaching is balanced by the sintering of the catalytic particles that occurs during FA hydroprocessing [78]. Carbon accumulation on the surface of the catalysts in the FAs hydroprocessing was estimated using CHNS analysis (Table 7). The largest amount of carbon detected on ZSM-5 supported catalyst is attributed to two primary factors: high yield of aromatics (that act as coke precursors) [79], and a relatively high content of AS [13,80] in these catalysts. Modification with Mo practically did not change the amount of carbon on the catalyst surface [78]. Table 8 features XRF and ICP-AES data for the fresh and spent catalysts. The amount of residual nickel from the XRF data was calculated by changing the Ni/Si ratio. Supports stability under reaction conditions is evidenced by the practically unchanged content of Al and Si in fresh and spent catalysts, as well as constancy of SAR (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio). Although XRF is a semi-quantitative method, the data obtained by both methods show similar values for the content of metals. All samples demonstrate a decrease in the amount of Ni and Mo after being used in FAs hydroprocessing. The largest amount (65 %) of residual nickel in monometallic catalysts was found in NiY, while NiZSM-5 lost ca. 49 % of the active component. Other catalysts lost intermediate amount of Ni, ranking as NiZSM-5 < NiMOR ~ NiZSM-23 < NiY. Ni stability under reaction conditions is attributed to several factors. For the case of NiMOR and NiZSM-23, larger particle size caused by sintering (see TEM) may stabilize Ni against an acid attack. Inversely, this may explain the lowest stability of NiZSM-5 featuring the smallest particle size of the active component, as well as the largest fraction of Ni reducible above 500 °C [77]. In the case of a catalyst based on zeolite Y, a high content of residual nickel can be associated with the process of dealumination in the zeolite particle, which leads to the destruction of the zeolite framework. The destruction of the structure can lead to the washing out of not only aluminum, but also silicon and nickel. Thus, a uniform leaching of all elements from the catalysts can occur, and therefore the final composition of the samples remains practically unchanged. Among the bimetallic catalysts, the largest amount of residual nickel was found in the MoNiY catalyst, which is most likely due to the destruction of the zeolite particle structure discussed above. For the systems supported on Y, MOR and ZSM-5, the amount of Mo remains virtually constant after FAs hydroprocessing, while for MoNiZSM-23, this figure decreases. Based on the residual Ni content, bimetallic catalysts are ranked as MoNiMOR ~ MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiY. As can be seen in Table 8, Mo-doping did not lead to a noticeably higher stability of Ni under reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions A series of Ni/zeolite catalysts, as well as a series of Mo-Ni/zeolite catalysts, were synthesized by the incipient wetness impregnation method. The influence of the support and modifier on the activity and selectivity of catalysts in the process of hydroprocessing of a mixture of fatty acids without the use of a solvent in a batch reactor, as well as on the degree of leaching of the active component of the catalyst, was studied. It was shown that among the mono- and bimetallic catalysts, the catalysts based on the ZSM-5 zeolite turned out to be the most active in hydroprocessing of a mixture of fatty acids. This is due to the formation in the catalyst of a significant amount of the high-temperature form of the active component, which is active in the process of hydrodeoxygenation of a mixture of fatty acids. The formation of the high-temperature form of the active component was determined by a combination of textural and acidic characteristics of the support. The conversion of the mixture of fatty acids in the presence of Ni and Ni-Mo catalysts correlated with the proportion of the high temperature form of the active component. The highest selectivity to isoalkanes among monometallic catalysts was achieved on NiZSM-5, and among bimetallic ones - on MoNiZSM-23. These zeolites seem to have an optimal channel size (5,1 × 5,5, 5,3 × 5,6 Å), which allows reagent molecules to freely penetrate into the channels and undergo hydrodeoxygenation and hydroisomerization reactions. Channels that are too large, as in the case of Y and MOR zeolites, allow molecules to diffuse too quickly, preventing linear alkanes from converting to iso-alkanes. The degree of interaction of the active component with the support surface determines the resistance of the active component to leaching. In the case of the Ni/zeolite series, nickel losses after the process increase in the following order: NiY < NiZSM-23 ~ NiMOR < Ni/ZSM-5. The modification of catalysts with molybdenum leads to a change in the series in terms of the amount of residual nickel: MoNiMOR < MoNiZSM-23 < MoNiZSM-5 < MoNiY, which correlates with the position series of the main reduction temperature maximum - the higher the reduction temperature of the active component, the more it remains in the spent catalyst. Catalysts on zeolite Y are out of the general dependence due to instability under the given conditions of the process of zeolite particles. These catalysts turned out to be subject to a bulk dealumination process, which is possible due to large channels (7,4 × 7,4 Å) in the Y zeolite structure. This phenomenon could not be detected on the other catalysts. Apparently, due to the smaller size of the channels, the deoxygenation of fatty acids for catalysts based on MOR, ZSM-23, and ZSM-5 zeolites occurs mainly on the outer surfaces of zeolite particles. This method of modifying nickel catalysts on zeolites — successive deposition of metal precursors — does not interfere with the deactivation of bimetallic catalysts, and also does not improve the catalytic characteristics of the catalysts under these process conditions. To increase the stability of nickel-based catalysts, it is expedient to carry out modification by simultaneous application of precursors of the bimetallic active component in order to increase the proportion of formed combined phases, as well as to increase the degree of interaction of the active component with the support surface. Based on this, in order to develop the direction of one-pot processing of plant lipids into motor fuel components, it is necessary to solve the problem of active component leaching by modifying the active component and choosing the optimal preparation method, which will increase the degree of interaction of the active component with the carrier surface. It is also necessary to select a zeolite with a suitable pore and channel structure that will provide the necessary transport of reactants and products, and with an acid-resistant structure. coredata.dc:description: Ni/zeolite catalyst, as well as a series of modified molybdenum MoNi/zeolite catalysts (zeolite = ZSM-5, ZSM-23, MOR, Y) were investigated in the hydroprocessing of an undiluted fatty acid mixture in a batch reactor at a temperature of 350 °C and an initial hydrogen pressure of 60 bar. The highest conversion (70 %) of the fatty acid mixture was achieved over ZSM-5 supported catalytic system in 7 h. The fresh and spent catalytic systems were characterized by XRD, TEM, TPR-H2, TPD-NH3, CHNS. Influence of the support, and the modifier, on the catalytic activity, stability under reaction conditions, and selectivity to iso-alkanes were shown. Leaching of the active component from the surface of all catalysts was found. The largest amount of residual nickel was observed in catalysts based on ZSM-5 zeolite - ca.57 % of the initial metal content. Modification with molybdenum did not improve the stability of catalysts to metal leaching.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the support on activity and stability of Ni and Ni-Mo catalysts in the hydroprocessing of fatty acids into motor fuels components
